query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान व्यायाम कैसे मदद करता है?
answer_hi: व्यायाम गर्भवती महिलाओं को वजन बढ़ने के लिए अनुकूलित करने में मदद करता है, प्रसव के लिए पेशियों को मजबूत करता है और गर्भावस्था की जटिलताओं की जोखिम को कम करता है।

context_en:
**Being pregnant is a big life event and it is natural to feel a lot of different emotions. But if you’re feeling sad and it’s starting to affect your life, there are things you can try that may help.**

Things you can try to help with your mental health
--------------------------------------------------

### Do

*   talk about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
    
*   try [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/self-help/guides-tools-and-activities/breathing-exercises-for-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
    
*   do physical activity if you can – it can improve your mood and help you sleep
    
*   eat a healthy diet with regular meals
    
*   try to attend [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
    

### Don’t

*   do not compare yourself to others – everyone experiences pregnancy in different ways
    
*   do not be afraid to tell healthcare professionals how you are feeling – they are there to listen and support you
    
*   do not use alcohol, cigarettes or drugs to try and feel better – these can make you feel worse and affect your baby's growth and wellbeing
    

### Non-urgent advice: Speak to your midwife or a doctor if:

*   things you're trying yourself are not helping

They can offer you support. They may offer you a referral to perinatal mental health services or other emotional support. Perinatal means the time you are pregnant and up to 12 months after giving birth.

NHS therapy and counselling services
------------------------------------

If you're feeling sad and it's not improving, a talking therapy might help.

There are different types of talking therapies for mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

Talking therapies include [cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) and [counselling](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/counselling/).

A GP can refer you for talking treatment, or you can refer yourself directly to an NHS talking therapies service without going to a GP. If you refer yourself, it's a good idea to talk to a midwife or GP as well about how you're feeling.

[Find an NHS talking therapies service](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/mental-health/find-an-NHS-talking-therapies-service/)

Medicine for mental health problems
-----------------------------------

You may be offered medicine to treat your symptoms.

If you decide to take medicine while you're pregnant or breastfeeding speak to your doctor. They will help you weigh up the risks and benefits, so you can decide on the best treatment for you and your baby.

They'll offer you the safest medicine at the lowest amount that will still work.

**Mental health problems**
--------------------------

There are many mental health problems you could experience in pregnancy. They can happen at any time, even if this is not your first pregnancy.

You may also find it hard to cope with your body changing shape, particularly if you have had an [eating disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/feelings-symptoms-behaviours/behaviours/eating-disorders/overview/).

Further support
---------------

You can [find care for your mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/mental-health-services/find-care-for-your-mental-health-before-during-and-after-pregnancy/).

Some charities and organisations offer support for mental health during pregnancy.

*   [Tommy's: mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/mental-health-during-and-after-pregnancy)  
    Call: 0800 014 7800 from Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm, for free  
    Email: midwife@tommys.org
*   [Mind: postnatal depression and perinatal mental health](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/postnatal-depression-and-perinatal-mental-health/about-maternal-mental-health-problems/)  
    Call: 0300 123 3393  
    Email: info@mind.org
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance: mental health support for mums and families](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/about-maternal-mental-health/support-mums-and-families/)
*   [NICE: Antenatal and postnatal mental health: clinical management and service guidance](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg192/ifp/chapter/questions-to-ask-about-mental-health-problems-in-pregnancy-and-the-year-after-birth) has some question ideas that might help you talk to your GP or midwife


==================================================

Content from https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/depression/:
query_en: What types of exercises are recommended during pregnancy?
answer_en: Light aerobic exercises like walking, swimming, and prenatal yoga are recommended during pregnancy as they are gentle and safe.
context_hi: * गर्भावस्था एक बड़ा जीवन घटना है और यह स्वाभाविक है कि आप कई भिन्न भावनाओं को महसूस करें. लेकिन यदि आप दुखी महसूस कर रहे हैं और यह आपके जीवन को प्रभावित करने के लिए शुरू हो रहा है, तो कुछ महसूस कर सकते हैं, विशेष रूप से यदि आपको एक आहार विकार [cognitive behavioural therapy गर्भावस्था से पहले, उसके दौरान और उसके बाद अपने मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के लिए देखभाल प्राप्त कर सकते हैं [counselling](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/counselling/). कुछ धर्मार्थ और संगठन गर्भावस्था के दौरान मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के लिए समर्थन प्रदान करते हैं. * टोमी के: गर्भावस्था से पहले, उसके दौरान और उसके बाद मानसिक स्वास्थ्य
query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान किन प्रकार के व्यायाम की सिफारिश की जाती है?
answer_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान हल्के एरोबिक व्यायाम जैसे हिदायत, तैराकी और प्रसवोत्तर योग की सिफारिश की जाती है क्योंकि वे हल्के और सुरक्षित हैं।

query_en: What are the risks of over-exercising during pregnancy?
answer_en: Over-exercising during pregnancy can lead to exhaustion and breathlessness, which may indicate that you are pushing your body too hard.

चीजें हैं जिन्हें आप प्रयास कर सकते हैं जो मदद कर सकते हैं. ** आप अपने मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के साथ मदद करने के लिए प्रयास कर सकते हैं------------------------------------------------- ### आप अपने भावनाओं के बारे में किसी मित्र, परिवार के सदस्य, चिकित्सक या मादर से बात करें * यदि आप तृप्त महसूस कर रहे हैं तो सांस लेने के व्यायाम करने की कोशिश करें [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/self-help/guides-tools-and-activities/breathing-exercises-for-stress/) * यदि आप शारीरिक व्यायाम कर सकते हैं तो यह आप की मनोदशा में सुधार ला सकता है और आपको सोने में मदद कर सकता है * नियमित भोजन के साथ एक स्वस्थ आहार खायें * प्रसूतिकालीन कक्षाओं में भाग लेने की कोशिश करें [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) अन्य लोगों से मिलने के लिए जो आप के साथ वे आपको जोखिमों और लाभों को तौलने में मदद करेंगे, ताकि आप आप और आपके बच्चे के लिए सर्वोत्तम उपचार पर निर्णय कर सकते हैं. वे आपको सबसे कम मात्रा में सुरक्षित औषधियां प्रदान करेंगे जो अभी भी काम करेंगे. **मानसिक स्वास्थ्य समस्याएं** -------------------------- गर्भावस्था में अनेक मानसिक स्वास्थ्य समस्याएं हैं जिन्हें आप अनुभव कर सकते हैं. वे किसी भी समय हो सकती हैं, चाहे यह आपका पहला गर्भावस्था न हो. आप अपने शरीर के आकार में परिवर्तन से निपटने में भी कठिनाई महसूस कर सकते हैं, विशेष रूप से यदि आपको एक आहार विकार [cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) हुआ है. अतिरिक्त समर्थन --------------- आप गर्भावस्था से पहले, उसके दौरान और उसके बाद अपने मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के लिए देखभाल प्राप्त कर सकते हैं [counselling](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/counselling/). कुछ धर्मार्थ और संगठन गर्भावस्था के दौरान मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के लिए समर्थन प्रदान करते हैं. * टोमी के: गर्भावस्था से पहले, उसके दौरान और उसके बाद मानसिक स्वास्थ्य
query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान किन कुछ व्यायामों से बचना चाहिए?
answer_hi: कुछ व्यायामों से बचना चाहिए क्योंकि वे गिरने या पेट पर दबाव डालने का खतरा पैदा करते हैं, जो शिशु को हानि पहुंचा सकता है।

context_en:
**Being pregnant is a big life event and it is natural to feel a lot of different emotions. But if you’re feeling sad and it’s starting to affect your life, there are things you can try that may help.**

Things you can try to help with your mental health
--------------------------------------------------

### Do

*   talk about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
    
*   try [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/self-help/guides-tools-and-activities/breathing-exercises-for-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
    
*   do physical activity if you can – it can improve your mood and help you sleep
    
*   eat a healthy diet with regular meals
    
*   try to attend [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
    

### Don’t

*   do not compare yourself to others – everyone experiences pregnancy in different ways
    
*   do not be afraid to tell healthcare professionals how you are feeling – they are there to listen and support you
    
*   do not use alcohol, cigarettes or drugs to try and feel better – these can make you feel worse and affect your baby's growth and wellbeing
    

### Non-urgent advice: Speak to your midwife or a doctor if:

*   things you're trying yourself are not helping

They can offer you support. They may offer you a referral to perinatal mental health services or other emotional support. Perinatal means the time you are pregnant and up to 12 months after giving birth.

NHS therapy and counselling services
------------------------------------

If you're feeling sad and it's not improving, a talking therapy might help.

There are different types of talking therapies for mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

Talking therapies include [cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) and [counselling](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/counselling/).

A GP can refer you for talking treatment, or you can refer yourself directly to an NHS talking therapies service without going to a GP. If you refer yourself, it's a good idea to talk to a midwife or GP as well about how you're feeling.

[Find an NHS talking therapies service](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/mental-health/find-an-NHS-talking-therapies-service/)

Medicine for mental health problems
-----------------------------------

You may be offered medicine to treat your symptoms.

If you decide to take medicine while you're pregnant or breastfeeding speak to your doctor. They will help you weigh up the risks and benefits, so you can decide on the best treatment for you and your baby.

They'll offer you the safest medicine at the lowest amount that will still work.

**Mental health problems**
--------------------------

There are many mental health problems you could experience in pregnancy. They can happen at any time, even if this is not your first pregnancy.

You may also find it hard to cope with your body changing shape, particularly if you have had an [eating disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/feelings-symptoms-behaviours/behaviours/eating-disorders/overview/).

Further support
---------------

You can [find care for your mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/mental-health-services/find-care-for-your-mental-health-before-during-and-after-pregnancy/).

Some charities and organisations offer support for mental health during pregnancy.

*   [Tommy's: mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/mental-health-during-and-after-pregnancy)  
    Call: 0800 014 7800 from Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm, for free  
    Email: midwife@tommys.org
*   [Mind: postnatal depression and perinatal mental health](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/postnatal-depression-and-perinatal-mental-health/about-maternal-mental-health-problems/)  
    Call: 0300 123 3393  
    Email: info@mind.org
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance: mental health support for mums and families](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/about-maternal-mental-health/support-mums-and-families/)
*   [NICE: Antenatal and postnatal mental health: clinical management and service guidance](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg192/ifp/chapter/questions-to-ask-about-mental-health-problems-in-pregnancy-and-the-year-after-birth) has some question ideas that might help you talk to your GP or midwife

query_en: Is swimming safe during pregnancy?
answer_en: Yes, swimming is safe during pregnancy, and many pools offer aqua-natal classes designed for expectant mothers.

query_hi: क्या गर्भावस्था के दौरान तैरना सुरक्षित है?
answer_hi: हाँ, गर्भावस्था के दौरान तैरना सुरक्षित है और कई तालाबों में expectant mothers के लिए तैयार किए गए aqua-natal कक्षाएं उपलब्ध हैं।

समर्थन प्रदान करते हैं. * टोमी के: गर्भावस्था से पहले, उसके दौरान और उसके बाद मानसिक स्वास्थ्य
query_hi: गर्भावस्था एक महिला के मानसिक स्वास्थ्य पर कैसे प्रभाव डाल सकती है?
answer_hi: गर्भावस्था में कई भावनाएं पैदा हो सकती हैं, जिनमें चिंता, निराशा या तनाव भी शामिल हैं, जो माता की समग्र कुशलता पर प्रभाव डाल सकते हैं।

context_en:
**Being pregnant is a big life event and it is natural to feel a lot of different emotions. But if you’re feeling sad and it’s starting to affect your life, there are things you can try that may help.**

Things you can try to help with your mental health
--------------------------------------------------

### Do

*   talk about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
    
*   try [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/self-help/guides-tools-and-activities/breathing-exercises-for-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
    
*   do physical activity if you can – it can improve your mood and help you sleep
    
*   eat a healthy diet with regular meals
    
*   try to attend [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
    

### Don’t

*   do not compare yourself to others – everyone experiences pregnancy in different ways
    
*   do not be afraid to tell healthcare professionals how you are feeling – they are there to listen and support you
    
*   do not use alcohol, cigarettes or drugs to try and feel better – these can make you feel worse and affect your baby's growth and wellbeing
    

### Non-urgent advice: Speak to your midwife or a doctor if:

*   things you're trying yourself are not helping

They can offer you support. They may offer you a referral to perinatal mental health services or other emotional support. Perinatal means the time you are pregnant and up to 12 months after giving birth.

NHS therapy and counselling services
------------------------------------

If you're feeling sad and it's not improving, a talking therapy might help.

There are different types of talking therapies for mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

Talking therapies include [cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) and [counselling](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/counselling/).

A GP can refer you for talking treatment, or you can refer yourself directly to an NHS talking therapies service without going to a GP. If you refer yourself, it's a good idea to talk to a midwife or GP as well about how you're feeling.

[Find an NHS talking therapies service](https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/mental-health/find-an-NHS-talking-therapies-service/)

Medicine for mental health problems
-----------------------------------

You may be offered medicine to treat your symptoms.

If you decide to take medicine while you're pregnant or breastfeeding speak to your doctor. They will help you weigh up the risks and benefits, so you can decide on the best treatment for you and your baby.

They'll offer you the safest medicine at the lowest amount that will still work.

**Mental health problems**
--------------------------

There are many mental health problems you could experience in pregnancy. They can happen at any time, even if this is not your first pregnancy.

You may also find it hard to cope with your body changing shape, particularly if you have had an [eating disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/feelings-symptoms-behaviours/behaviours/eating-disorders/overview/).

Further support
---------------

You can [find care for your mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/mental-health-services/find-care-for-your-mental-health-before-during-and-after-pregnancy/).

Some charities and organisations offer support for mental health during pregnancy.

*   [Tommy's: mental health before, during and after pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/mental-health-during-and-after-pregnancy)  
    Call: 0800 014 7800 from Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm, for free  
    Email: midwife@tommys.org
*   [Mind: postnatal depression and perinatal mental health](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/postnatal-depression-and-perinatal-mental-health/about-maternal-mental-health-problems/)  
    Call: 0300 123 3393  
    Email: info@mind.org
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance: mental health support for mums and families](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/about-maternal-mental-health/support-mums-and-families/)
*   [NICE: Antenatal and postnatal mental health: clinical management and service guidance](https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg192/ifp/chapter/questions-to-ask-about-mental-health-problems-in-pregnancy-and-the-year-after-birth) has some question ideas that might help you talk to your GP or midwife


==================================================

Content from https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/depression/:
query_en: What should a pregnant woman do if she feels sad or overwhelmed?
answer_en: If a pregnant woman feels sad or overwhelmed, she should talk to a healthcare provider, midwife, or a trusted person, and seek support if necessary.

query_en: What are the signs of antenatal depression?
answer_en: Signs of antenatal depression include persistent sadness, lack of interest in things, irritability, and trouble concentrating.

query_hi: जन्मपूर्व नैराशंस के लक्षण क्या हैं?
answer_hi: जन्मपूर्व नैराशितता के लक्षणों में लगातार उदासी, वस्तुओं में रुचि की कमी, उग्रता और एकाग्रता में परेशानी शामिल हैं।

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: Why is maintaining a balanced diet during pregnancy essential?
answer_en: Maintaining a balanced diet during pregnancy is essential because it provides all the necessary nutrients for the baby's growth and development, while supporting the mother's health.

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours


==================================================

query_en: Is it necessary to 'eat for two' during pregnancy?
answer_en: No, there's no need to 'eat for two.' While pregnant women may feel hungrier, they should focus on eating healthy meals rather than increasing portion sizes significantly.

query_en: What types of foods are beneficial during pregnancy?
answer_en: Fruits, vegetables, starchy foods, and protein-rich foods such as lean meat, fish, and beans are beneficial during pregnancy.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान कौन सी प्रकार के भोजन लाभदायक होते हैं?

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: Why should folic acid supplements be taken during pregnancy?
answer_en: Folic acid supplements should be taken to help prevent birth defects, such as neural tube defects like spina bifida.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान फॉलिक एसिड अनुपूरक क्यों लिया जाना चाहिए?
answer_hi: फॉलिक एसिड पूरक लेने से जन्म दोषों को रोकने में मदद की जानी चाहिए, जैसे तंत्रिका नलिका दोष जैसे स्पाइन बीफिडा।

query_en: Can a healthy diet prevent common pregnancy issues?
answer_en: Yes, a healthy diet can help prevent issues such as constipation and excessive weight gain, and can support healthy digestion during pregnancy.

query_hi: क्या स्वस्थ आहार सामान्य गर्भावस्था की समस्याओं को रोक सकता है?
answer_hi: हो सकता है कि स्वस्थ आहार से कब्ज और अत्यधिक वजन बढ़ने जैसी समस्याओं को रोकने में मदद मिलती है और गर्भावस्था के दौरान स्वस्थ पाचन में मदद मिलती है।

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: How does exercise help during pregnancy?
answer_en: Exercise helps pregnant women adapt to weight gain, strengthens muscles for labour, and reduces the risk of pregnancy complications.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान व्यायाम कैसे मदद करता है?
answer_hi: व्यायाम गर्भवती महिलाओं को वजन बढ़ने के लिए अनुकूलित करने में मदद करता है, प्रसव के लिए पेशियों को मजबूत करता है और गर्भावस्था की जटिलताओं की जोखिम को कम करता है।

query_en: What types of exercises are recommended during pregnancy?
answer_en: Light aerobic exercises like walking, swimming, and prenatal yoga are recommended during pregnancy as they are gentle and safe.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान किन प्रकार के व्यायाम की सिफारिश की जाती है?
answer_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान हल्के एरोबिक व्यायाम जैसे हिदायत, तैराकी और प्रसवोत्तर योग की सिफारिश की जाती है क्योंकि वे हल्के और सुरक्षित हैं।

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: What are the risks of over-exercising during pregnancy?
answer_en: Over-exercising during pregnancy can lead to exhaustion and breathlessness, which may indicate that you are pushing your body too hard.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान अधिक व्यायाम करने के जोखिम क्या हैं?
answer_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान अधिक व्यायाम करने से थकान और दमन हो सकता है, जिससे यह पता चलता है कि आप अपने शरीर को बहुत जोर से दबा रहे हैं।

query_en: Why should certain exercises be avoided during pregnancy?
answer_en: Certain exercises should be avoided because they pose a risk of falling or pressure on the belly, which could harm the baby.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान किन कुछ व्यायामों से बचना चाहिए?
answer_hi: कुछ व्यायामों से बचना चाहिए क्योंकि वे गिरने या पेट पर दबाव डालने का खतरा पैदा करते हैं, जो शिशु को हानि पहुंचा सकता है।

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: Is swimming safe during pregnancy?
answer_en: Yes, swimming is safe during pregnancy, and many pools offer aqua-natal classes designed for expectant mothers.

query_hi: क्या गर्भावस्था के दौरान तैरना सुरक्षित है?

query_en: How can pregnancy affect a woman's mental health?
answer_en: Pregnancy can lead to a range of emotions, including anxiety, depression, or stress, which can impact the mother's overall well-being.

context_en:
**You can get depression when you are pregnant. This is called antenatal depression.**

With help and support most people with antenatal depression are able to manage the condition.

If antenatal depression is not treated symptoms can get worse and may continue after the baby is born ([postnatal depression](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/post-natal-depression/overview/)). So it is important to get help if you need it.

Symptoms
--------

Some mood changes are normal in pregnancy, like feeling tired or irritable. But if you’re feeling low and hopeless all the time, and no longer enjoy the things you used to, talk to a midwife or GP.

Signs and symptoms of antenatal depression include:

*   feeling sad, a low mood, or tearful a lot of the time
*   feeling irritable, or getting angry easily
*   losing interest in other people and the world around you
*   not wanting to eat or eating more than usual
*   negative thoughts, such as worrying you will not be able to look after your baby
*   feeling guilty, hopeless or blaming yourself for your problems
*   having problems concentrating or making decisions

Urgent advice: Contact a GP immediately if:
-------------------------------------------

You, or a friend or relative who is pregnant:

*   starts hearing or seeing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   develop strong beliefs not shared by others (delusions)

If it is not possible to contact a GP, call [NHS 111](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/when-to-use-111/) or your local [out-of-hours service](https://www.nhs.uk/nhs-services/urgent-and-emergency-care-services/nhs-out-of-hours-services/).

Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

*   you think there is a danger that you might harm yourself or others
*   you are worried that someone else might harm themselves or others

Treatment
---------

Speak to a GP or your midwife as soon as possible if you think you might have antenatal depression.

With appropriate treatment and support, most people are able to manage their symptoms, though it can take time.

### Self-help

A GP or midwife may recommend a number of self-help tips that can help improve your mood. These include:

*   talking about your feelings to a friend, family member, doctor or midwife
*   trying [calming breathing exercises](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/stress-anxiety-depression/ways-relieve-stress/) if you feel overwhelmed
*   increasing [physical activity](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/exercise/) levels if you can as it can improve your mood and help you sleep
*   attending [antenatal classes](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/preparing-for-the-birth/antenatal-classes/) to meet others who are expecting babies around the same time as you
*   eating a [healthy diet](https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/)

### Psychological therapy

A GP may recommend a self-help course or refer you for therapy, such as [cognitive behavioural therapy](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/talking-therapies-medicine-treatments/talking-therapies-and-counselling/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/overview/) (CBT) or counselling.

It may take several weeks to see a therapist or counsellor. CBT can be done ‘face to face’ with a counsellor or online, using a computer.

A GP should be able to explain more about different ways you can have CBT.

### Antidepressants

Antidepressant medicines may be recommended for you if you have moderate or severe depression and:

*   you do not want to use psychological therapy
*   psychological therapy has not worked for you
*   you prefer to take medicine

Some people may benefit from having both psychological therapy and taking antidepressants.

Talk to a GP (or doctor in charge of your care) about antidepressants that are safer to take during pregnancy.

The doctor will usually offer the type with the lowest risk for you and your baby.

Your doctor can explain the risks and the benefits, and will help you decide which treatment is best for you and your baby.

Find out more about [antidepressants and pregnancy on the Mind website](https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/drugs-and-treatments/antidepressants/antidepressants-in-pregnancy/).

You can search for your medicine on [Bumps medicines you can use in pregnancy A-Z](https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/)

Further support
---------------

*   [Pre and Postnatal Depression Advice and Support (PANDAS)](https://pandasfoundation.org.uk/)
*   [NCT (the National Childbirth Trust): How you might be feeling](https://www.nct.org.uk/pregnancy/how-you-might-be-feeling)
*   [Maternal Mental Health Alliance](https://maternalmentalhealthalliance.org/campaign/)
*   [Tommy’s: Depression in pregnancy](https://www.tommys.org/pregnancy-information/im-pregnant/mental-wellbeing/depression-pregnancy)

### **Other mental health conditions**

Other mental health conditions that can develop during pregnancy, or get worse because you are pregnant, include:

*   [anxiety disorders](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/generalised-anxiety-disorder/overview/), including generalised anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and panic disorder
*   [obsessive compulsive disorder](https://www.nhs.uk/mental-health/conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder-ocd/overview/) (OCD), where intrusive, unwanted and unpleasant thoughts, images or urges repeatedly enter a person's mind, causing them anxiety and leading to repetitive behaviours

query_en: What should a pregnant woman do if she feels sad or overwhelmed?
answer_en: If a pregnant woman feels sad or overwhelmed, she should talk to a healthcare provider, midwife, or a trusted person, and seek support if necessary.

query_hi: गर्भवती महिला को क्या करना चाहिए यदि वह दुखी या विचलित हो जाती है?
answer_hi: यदि कोई गर्भवती महिला दुखी या विचलित महसूस करती है तो उसे किसी स्वास्थ्य देखभाल प्रदाता, मादर या किसी विश्वसनीय व्यक्ति से बात करनी चाहिए और यदि आवश्यक हो तो सहायता की तलाश करनी चाहिए।

query_en: What are the signs of antenatal depression?
answer_en: Signs of antenatal depression include persistent sadness, lack of interest in things, irritability, and trouble concentrating.

query_hi: जन्मपूर्व नैराशंस के लक्षण क्या हैं?
answer_hi: जन्मपूर्व नैराशितता के लक्षणों में लगातार उदासी, वस्तुओं में रुचि की कमी, उग्रता और एकाग्रता में परेशानी शामिल हैं।

context_en:
With the proper precautions such as travel insurance, most women can travel safely well into their pregnancy.

Wherever you go, find out what healthcare facilities are at your destination in case you need urgent medical attention. It's a good idea to take your maternity medical records (sometimes called handheld notes) with you so you can give doctors the relevant information if necessary.

Find out more about [getting healthcare abroad](https://www.nhs.uk/using-the-nhs/healthcare-abroad/).

Make sure your travel insurance covers you for any eventuality, such as pregnancy-related medical care during labour, premature birth and the cost of changing the date of your return trip if you go into [labour](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/signs-of-labour/signs-that-labour-has-begun/).

When to travel in pregnancy
---------------------------

Some women prefer not to travel in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy because of [nausea and vomiting](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/related-conditions/common-symptoms/vomiting-and-morning-sickness/) and feeling very tired during these early stages. The risk of [miscarriage](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/miscarriage/) is also higher in the first 3 months, whether you're travelling or not.

Travelling in the final months of pregnancy can be tiring and uncomfortable. So, many women find the best time to travel or take a holiday is in mid-pregnancy, between 4 and 6 months.

Flying in pregnancy
-------------------

Flying isn't harmful to you or your baby, but discuss any health issues or pregnancy complications with your midwife or doctor before you fly.

The chance of going into labour is naturally higher after [37 weeks](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/week-by-week/28-to-40-plus/37-weeks/) (around 32 weeks if you're carrying twins), and some airlines won't let you fly towards the end of your pregnancy. Check with the airline for their policy on this.

After week 28 of pregnancy, the airline may ask for a letter from your doctor or midwife confirming your due date, and that you are not at risk of complications. You may have to pay for the letter and wait several weeks before you get it.

Long-distance travel (longer than 4 hours) carries a small risk of blood clots [(deep vein thrombosis (DVT))](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/deep-vein-thrombosis-dvt/). If you fly, drink plenty of water and move about regularly – every 30 minutes or so. You can buy a pair of graduated compression or support stockings from the pharmacy, which will help reduce leg swelling.

Travel vaccinations when you're pregnant
----------------------------------------

Most vaccines that use live bacteria or viruses aren't recommended during pregnancy because of concerns that they could harm the baby in the womb.

However, some live travel vaccines may be considered during pregnancy if the risk of infection outweighs the risk of live vaccination. Ask your GP or midwife for advice about specific travel vaccinations. Non-live (inactivated) vaccines are safe to use in pregnancy.

Malaria tablets
---------------

Some anti-malaria tablets aren't safe to take in pregnancy so ask your GP for advice.

Zika virus
----------

[Zika virus](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/zika/) is mainly spread by mosquitoes found in some parts of the world. For most people it's mild and not harmful, but can cause problems if you're pregnant.

If you are pregnant, it is not recommended to travel to parts of the world where the Zika virus is present, such as parts of:

*   South and Central America
*   the Caribbean
*   the Pacific islands
*   Africa
*   Asia

### Check before you travel

It's important to check the risk for the country you're going to before you travel.

[Find out more about the Zika virus risk in specific countries on the Travel Health Pro website](https://travelhealthpro.org.uk/countries)

Car travel in pregnancy
-----------------------

It's best to avoid long car journeys if you're pregnant. However, if it can't be avoided, make sure you stop regularly and get out of the car to stretch and move around.

You can also do some exercises in the car (when you're not driving), such as flexing and rotating your feet and wiggling your toes. This will keep the blood flowing through your legs and reduce any stiffness and discomfort. Wearing compression stockings while on long car journeys (more than 4 hours) can also increase the blood flow in your legs and help prevent blood clots.

Tiredness and dizziness are common during pregnancy so it's important on car journeys to drink regularly and eat natural, energy-giving foods, such as fruit and nuts.

Keep the air circulating in the car and wear your seatbelt with the cross strap between your breasts and the lap strap across your pelvis under your bump, not across your bump.

Road accidents are among the most common causes of injury in pregnant women. If you have to make a long trip, don't travel on your own. You could also share the driving with your companion.

Sailing in pregnancy
--------------------

Ferry companies have their own restrictions and may refuse to carry heavily pregnant women (often beyond 32 weeks on standard crossings and 28 weeks on high-speed crossings ). Check the ferry company's policy before you book.

For longer boat trips, such as cruises, find out if there are onboard facilities to deal with pregnancy and medical services at the docking ports.

Food and drink abroad in pregnancy
----------------------------------

Take care to avoid food- and water-borne conditions, such as stomach upsets and travellers' [diarrhoea](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/). Some medicines for treating stomach upsets and travellers' diarrhoea aren't suitable during pregnancy.

Always check if tap water is safe to drink. If in doubt, drink bottled water. If you get ill, keep hydrated and continue eating for the health of your baby, even if you're not hungry.

Find out about a [healthy diet in pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/have-a-healthy-diet/), and [foods to avoid in pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/foods-to-avoid/).

query_en: Why is maintaining a balanced diet during pregnancy essential?
answer_en: Maintaining a balanced diet during pregnancy is essential because it provides all the necessary nutrients for the baby's growth and development, while supporting the mother's health.

query_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान संतुलित आहार बनाए रखना क्यों अनिवार्य है?
answer_hi: गर्भावस्था के दौरान संतुलित आहार बनाए रखना आवश्यक है क्योंकि यह बच्चे के विकास और विकास के लिए सभी आवश्यक पोषक तत्व प्रदान करता है और साथ ही मां के स्वास्थ्य का समर्थन करता है।

query_en: Is it necessary to 'eat for two' during pregnancy?
answer_en: No, there's no need to 'eat for two.' While pregnant women may feel hungrier, they should focus on eating healthy meals rather than increasing portion sizes significantly.

context_en:
With the proper precautions such as travel insurance, most women can travel safely well into their pregnancy.

Wherever you go, find out what healthcare facilities are at your destination in case you need urgent medical attention. It's a good idea to take your maternity medical records (sometimes called handheld notes) with you so you can give doctors the relevant information if necessary.

Find out more about [getting healthcare abroad](https://www.nhs.uk/using-the-nhs/healthcare-abroad/).

Make sure your travel insurance covers you for any eventuality, such as pregnancy-related medical care during labour, premature birth and the cost of changing the date of your return trip if you go into [labour](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/labour-and-birth/signs-of-labour/signs-that-labour-has-begun/).

When to travel in pregnancy
---------------------------

Some women prefer not to travel in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy because of [nausea and vomiting](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/related-conditions/common-symptoms/vomiting-and-morning-sickness/) and feeling very tired during these early stages. The risk of [miscarriage](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/miscarriage/) is also higher in the first 3 months, whether you're travelling or not.

Travelling in the final months of pregnancy can be tiring and uncomfortable. So, many women find the best time to travel or take a holiday is in mid-pregnancy, between 4 and 6 months.

Flying in pregnancy
-------------------

Flying isn't harmful to you or your baby, but discuss any health issues or pregnancy complications with your midwife or doctor before you fly.

The chance of going into labour is naturally higher after [37 weeks](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/week-by-week/28-to-40-plus/37-weeks/) (around 32 weeks if you're carrying twins), and some airlines won't let you fly towards the end of your pregnancy. Check with the airline for their policy on this.

After week 28 of pregnancy, the airline may ask for a letter from your doctor or midwife confirming your due date, and that you are not at risk of complications. You may have to pay for the letter and wait several weeks before you get it.

Long-distance travel (longer than 4 hours) carries a small risk of blood clots [(deep vein thrombosis (DVT))](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/deep-vein-thrombosis-dvt/). If you fly, drink plenty of water and move about regularly – every 30 minutes or so. You can buy a pair of graduated compression or support stockings from the pharmacy, which will help reduce leg swelling.

Travel vaccinations when you're pregnant
----------------------------------------

Most vaccines that use live bacteria or viruses aren't recommended during pregnancy because of concerns that they could harm the baby in the womb.

However, some live travel vaccines may be considered during pregnancy if the risk of infection outweighs the risk of live vaccination. Ask your GP or midwife for advice about specific travel vaccinations. Non-live (inactivated) vaccines are safe to use in pregnancy.

Malaria tablets
---------------

Some anti-malaria tablets aren't safe to take in pregnancy so ask your GP for advice.

Zika virus
----------

[Zika virus](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/zika/) is mainly spread by mosquitoes found in some parts of the world. For most people it's mild and not harmful, but can cause problems if you're pregnant.

If you are pregnant, it is not recommended to travel to parts of the world where the Zika virus is present, such as parts of:

*   South and Central America
*   the Caribbean
*   the Pacific islands
*   Africa
*   Asia

### Check before you travel

It's important to check the risk for the country you're going to before you travel.

[Find out more about the Zika virus risk in specific countries on the Travel Health Pro website](https://travelhealthpro.org.uk/countries)

Car travel in pregnancy
-----------------------

It's best to avoid long car journeys if you're pregnant. However, if it can't be avoided, make sure you stop regularly and get out of the car to stretch and move around.

You can also do some exercises in the car (when you're not driving), such as flexing and rotating your feet and wiggling your toes. This will keep the blood flowing through your legs and reduce any stiffness and discomfort. Wearing compression stockings while on long car journeys (more than 4 hours) can also increase the blood flow in your legs and help prevent blood clots.

Tiredness and dizziness are common during pregnancy so it's important on car journeys to drink regularly and eat natural, energy-giving foods, such as fruit and nuts.

Keep the air circulating in the car and wear your seatbelt with the cross strap between your breasts and the lap strap across your pelvis under your bump, not across your bump.

Road accidents are among the most common causes of injury in pregnant women. If you have to make a long trip, don't travel on your own. You could also share the driving with your companion.

Sailing in pregnancy
--------------------

Ferry companies have their own restrictions and may refuse to carry heavily pregnant women (often beyond 32 weeks on standard crossings and 28 weeks on high-speed crossings ). Check the ferry company's policy before you book.

For longer boat trips, such as cruises, find out if there are onboard facilities to deal with pregnancy and medical services at the docking ports.

Food and drink abroad in pregnancy
----------------------------------

Take care to avoid food- and water-borne conditions, such as stomach upsets and travellers' [diarrhoea](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/). Some medicines for treating stomach upsets and travellers' diarrhoea aren't suitable during pregnancy.

Always check if tap water is safe to drink. If in doubt, drink bottled water. If you get ill, keep hydrated and continue eating for the health of your baby, even if you're not hungry.

Find out about a [healthy diet in pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/have-a-healthy-diet/), and [foods to avoid in pregnancy](https://www.nhs.uk/pregnancy/keeping-well/foods-to-avoid/).

query_en: What types of foods are beneficial during pregnancy?
answer_en: Fruits, vegetables, starchy foods, and protein-rich foods such as lean meat, fish, and beans are beneficial during pregnancy.

query_en: Why should folic acid supplements be taken during pregnancy?
answer_en: Folic acid supplements should be taken to help prevent birth defects, such as neural tube defects like spina bifida.
